results.title: The Powers that be
results.creator_credit: David Richardson, Lorna Pegram, BBC and RM Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Shock of the New Series”.
Part 2 of an 8-part series which presents a social history of the impact and development of the visual arts in the 20th century by art critic and writer, Robert Hughes. In this episode Hughes examines how World War I and politics influenced art by way of the development of Dadaism in Germany and Constructivism in Russia. He also explores how architecture moved from modernism to a more classical style as a result of preferences displayed by Hitler and Mussolini.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Richardson, Lorna Pegram, BBC and RM Productions

results.title: The Mechanical paradise
results.creator_credit: David Richardson, Lorna Pegram, BBC-TV, RM Productions and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Shock of the New Series”.
This opening episode, of an 8-part series, covers the blend of art and industry, and shows how a growing belief in technology and the machine heralded the arrival of modernity. The Eiffel Tower in Paris, designed by an engineer not an architect, established the cult of dynamism, spread through railway stations, by automobile and the increasing advances in technology. The Cubists put onto canvas what is visually interpreted. Picasso and Braque’s influence by African carving distortions modified relationships and thought, and led to collage using industrial items and household objects incorporated on the canvas. Delaunay’s light through structure, Apollinaire’s poetry, Marinetti, Duchamp and Picabia blended all forms of artistic expression at once.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Richardson, Lorna Pegram, BBC-TV, RM Productions and Time-Life Films

results.title: The World: A Television History
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Barton, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest and Network Television
results.brief_description: A series of 26 videos presenting a history of humankind from its origins to the shaping of the modern world. The series looks at significant developments and great historical achievements in culture, science, technology, war, society, religion and all aspects of man’s progress. Based on the Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 26. The Modern World
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This is the final episode of the series that covers the history of man’s progress in the world, from the very beginning of human origins through to the world we know today. This episode covers the major historical events that occurred in world history over the period from 1945 to the present - including the introduction of Atomic bombs; the Vietnam conflicts; and the emergence of a Space Exploration program. Based on The Times atlas of world history.
results.title_for_label: The World: A Television History. Ep. 26. The Modern World
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Selwyn Gilbert, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest TV and Network Television

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 25. World in Conflict
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 25 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
From the 1930’s depression came the rise of political leaders/ radicals. One such person was Adolf Hitler, who created a re-armed Germany. With this power Hitler conquered countries, including Poland. Britain and France declared war on Germany, and Japan bombed Pearl Harbour. America, Britain and Russia became allies - their strategy was firstly to fight Germany and then to fight Japan. The war period saw the creation of military machines and the invention of the atomic bomb, which was later to be used on Japan.
results.title_for_label: The World: A Television History. Ep. 25. World in Conflict
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Selwyn Gilbert, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest TV and Network Television

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 24. The End of the Old Order
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 24 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode examines the end of a period of European history, and the emergence of prosperity for the United States of America over the years 1914-1929. In 1914, European civilisation dominated the world, with Britain and France the major players, and Germany and Italy eager to replace them. This was the time of World War I, and by 1919, Europe was reshaped. The decade following, however, was one of immense prosperity for the United States of America. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

This was the time of World War I, and by 1919, Europe was reshaped. The decade following, however, was one of immense prosperity for the United States of America. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 23. Industry and Empire
results.creator_credit: David Wright, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 23 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
From 1870 onwards the world changed with great speed. The British Empire took over a quarter of the world’s surface. Food prices, due to improved transportations had lowered, turning the peoples’ expenditures to entertainment rather than sustenance. Technology and invention were abundant; so too were towns and cities. The 1890’s saw the build up of military forces with advancements in weapons and ships. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 22. The Making of the United States of America
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 22 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode covers the evolution of the United States of America, over the period 1776 - 1890, from its struggle for independence through to the Civil War, and the abolishment of slavery. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 21. The Making of Russia
results.creator_credit: David Wright, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 21 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode looks at Russian history over the period 1480 - 1860. Initially, the Russian people were scattered tribes inhabiting the vast expanse of Eastern Europe, but over the centuries different leaders conquered the regions and attempted to create cohesive civilisations. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 20. The Age of Revolutions
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
Over the period 1776 - 1848, many parts of the world experienced revolutions of differing types, resulting in major upheavals to the civilisations involved. The major events of world history examined in this episode include, the Napoleonic era and the French Revolution, the Industrial Revolution of England, and the rebellion of the peasants in Russia. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.creator_credit_for_label: John Selwyn Gilbert, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
